The First Book of Geometry.
A brief instruction on what and upon what
Geometry is founded, and how one / according to the guidance of the same / with the compass and straightedge / should divide all kinds of lines / surfaces / and bodies / and in a given proposition / should make. Compiled from proven teachings / of the aforementioned liberal art / for all enthusiasts of the same / as an introduction / and for all skilled craftsmen for special use and advantage.
By Wolfgang Schmid, Master of Calculation
in Bamberg.
The art that stands in Euclid
Is far too hidden for many
Here it is made very easy and simple
Through this guidance / well considered.
Printed in Nuremberg.

Privilege for VI years.

title:
ANITII MANLII SEVERINI BOETHI IN OMNIBVS PHILO-
SOPHIAE PARTIBVS INTER LAtinos & Græcos autores principis OPERA, quæ extant, omnia, non solum liberalium disciplinarum, sed maiorum facultatum studiosis etiam utilissima. sine quibus Aristoteles in præcipuis locis intellegi non potest. Quare summi uiri rectè censebant, uerè studiosum non esse in cuius bibliotheca hic autor non erat. Porrò, infinitis locis non aliquot uoces, sed longas periodos quæ in prioribus æditionibus desiderabantur, emendauimus, adiuti praesidio uetustissimorum manuscriptorum exemplarium, & auxilio doctissimorum uirorum: Inter quos in omni literarum genere summus uir HENRICHVS LORITVS GLAREANVS Arithmeticam & Musicam demonstrationibus & figuris auctiorem redditam suo pristino nitori restituit, cui exemplar aureum uenerandæque uetustatis fuit ex monasterio S. Georgij. Et MARTIANVS ROTA opus de tota differendi ratione, hoc est, organum, Dialecticæ & Rhetoricæ studiosis necessarium, illustrauit. Et huius autoris uitam certis coniecturis, cum ex alijs, tum ex Boëthi monumentis collectam, bona fide descripsit.
title_EN: THE WORKS OF ANICIUS MANLIUS SEVERINUS BOETHIUS, THE FOREMOST AUTHOR IN ALL PARTS OF PHILOSOPHY AMONG LATIN AND GREEK AUTHORS, which are extant, all of them, not only most useful to students of the liberal disciplines, but also to those of the higher faculties. Without which, Aristotle cannot be understood in the principal places. Therefore, the greatest men rightly judged that one was not truly a student in whose library this author was not present. Furthermore, in countless places, we have corrected not just some words, but long periods that were missing in previous editions, aided by the support of the oldest manuscript copies, and the assistance of the most learned men: Among whom, in every kind of literature, the greatest man HENRICHUS LORITUS GLAREANUS restored Arithmetic and Music, made more complete with demonstrations and figures, to their former splendor, for which an exemplar of golden and venerable antiquity was from the monastery of St. George. And MARTIANUS ROTA illustrated the work on the entire method of differentiating, that is, the organ, necessary for students of Dialectic and Rhetoric. And he faithfully described the life of this author, collected with certain conjectures, both from others and from Boethius's own monuments.
OTHER NAMES: Aristoteles, HENRICHVS LORITVS GLAREANVS, MARTIANVS ROTA

title:
ANITII MANLII SEVERINI BOETHI, PHILOSOPHORVM
ET THEOLOGORVM PRINCIPIS OPERA omnia, quorum alia antè impressa, nunc denuò per doctos uiros recognita: alia, quæ hactenus latuerunt, nunc primùm emendatiss. in lucem prodeunt. In quibus præter uniuersæ philosophiæ exactissimam doctrinam, pluri-morum in diuinis mysteriorum, & diiciliorum locorum in Platone, Aristotele alijsque Græcis & Latinis autoribus luculentissimæ expli-cationes reperiuntur. PRAETEREA IAM ACCESSERVNT, Ioannis Murmelij in v. Lib. De Consolatione Philosophiæ commentaria. Et in eosdem Rodolphi Agricolæ Enarrationes. Item, Gilberti Porretæ, Episcopi Pictauiensis in IIII. Lib. de Trinitate commentarij, antè nun-quam æditi.  Præter reliquos doctiss. uiros, HENRICVS LORITVS
GLAREANVS, Arithmeticam & Musicam demonstrationibus & figuris auctiorem redditam, suo pristino nitori restituit: Cui exemplar aureum uenerandæque uetustatis fuit ex monasterio S. Georgij. Et MAR-TIANVS ROTA, opus de tota differendi ratione, hoc est, organum, Dialecticæ & Rhetoricæ studiosis necessarium, illustrauit. Et huius autoris uitam, cùm ex alijs, tum ex Boëthi munumentis collectam, bona fide descripsit.
title_EN:
THE COMPLETE WORKS OF ANICIUS MANLIUS SEVERINUS BOETHIUS, PRINCE OF PHILOSOPHERS
AND THEOLOGIANS, some of which were previously printed, now newly reviewed by learned men: others, which have remained hidden until now, are now for the first time published in a most corrected form. In which, besides the most exact doctrine of universal philosophy, the most splendid explanations of many divine mysteries, and the more difficult passages in Plato, Aristotle, and other Greek and Latin authors are found. FURTHERMORE, THERE HAVE NOW BEEN ADDED, the commentaries of Johannes Murmelius on the five books of The Consolation of Philosophy. And the Explanations on the same by Rodolphus Agricola. Also, the commentaries of Gilbert Porreta, Bishop of Poitiers, on the four books on the Trinity, never before published. Besides other most learned men, HENRICUS LORITUS
GLAREANUS, has restored Arithmetic and Music, made more complete with demonstrations and figures, to their former splendor: For whom a golden example of venerable antiquity was from the monastery of St. George. And MARTIANUS ROTA, has illustrated the work on the entire method of differentiating, that is, the organ, necessary for students of Dialectics and Rhetoric. And he has faithfully described the life of this author, collected from both other sources and Boethius's own monuments.
OTHER NAMES: Platone, Aristotele, Ioannis Murmelij, Rodolphi Agricolæ, Gilberti Porretæ, HENRICVS LORITVS GLAREANVS, MAR-TIANVS ROTA

NICERON,

THAUMATURGE,
OR
WONDERS

OF OPTICS, by direct rays;
OF CATOPTRICS, by reflection from polished bodies, plane, cylindrical,
conical, polyhedral, polygonal, and others;
OF DIOPTRICS, by refraction in transparent bodies.

In which, besides the foundations of scenography or common perspective, very easy
practices and demonstrations are shown, as well as prescriptions for all kinds of
regular solids, simple and composite, and irregular multiform ones, polyhedra,
star-shaped, perforated, and also architectural models, military diagrams, and countless
other spectacles in drawing: together with the surest and most expeditious rules, for the
three modes of vision — direct, reflected, and refracted — for delineating figures of
whatever deformed and disproportioned shapes upon any surface, so that when viewed
from a fixed point they appear proportioned, pleasing, and consistent with the laws of
painting and symmetry; indeed, even most similar to any given object.

A curious and useful work for Painters, Architects, Sculptors, Engravers, and all
others whose work lies in the study of drawing.
